dataset.title: Vegetation, soils, and environmental data in Arctic Riparian Shrublands, North Slope Alaska, 2016

abstract.para: These data pertain to vegetation, soils, and ecological site-factors sampled in August 2016 in Arctic riparian shrublands near the Dalton Highway in northern Alaska. Data were collected using an Ecological Land Survey approach as part of a multi-disciplinary study of ecohydrological relationships between shrubs and stream discharge in continuous permafrost environments. Shrub expansion along riparian corridors is a phenomenon that has been observed across the pan-Arctic in recent decades. Increasing air temperatures are often cited as the primary driver of shrub increase, which, in turn, has been documented to show warm soils in winter due to increased snow accumulation. Complex interactions between shrubland development and permafrost conditions raise the question of whether Arctic shrubs are initiating shifts in ground temperature and hydrologic regime, or simply taking advantage of improved conditions brought on by climate change.

intellectualRights.para: This work is dedicated to the public domain under the Creative Commons Universal 1.0 Public Domain Dedication. To view a copy of this dedication, visit https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: North Slope, Alaska along Dalton Highway corridor north of Toolik Field Station

section.title: Ecological sampling
section.para:
Ecological field plots were established in riparian vegetation along discrete stream reaches, 2 or 3 plots per stream reach. Ecological measurements focused on vegetation species-composition, canopy structure, and soil characteristics. The measurements included:
Visual species-cover estimation of all shrub species and of dominant herbaceous and nonvascular taxa
Leaf Area Index (LAI)
Maximum shrub canopy height
Thaw depth
Categorical descriptions of surficial geology and geomorphic landforms
Basic soil stratigraphy
Soil chemistry (pH and electrical conductivity [EC]) Ecological field plots were 20 m in length and oriented parallel to the adjacent stream section, with widths ranging 2‚Äê10 m depending on the size and configuration of the riparian shrub patch. Species-cover estimates were developed for the entire plot and included an independent cover estimate for plant functional type (e.g., tall/low/dwarf deciduous shrub, graminoid, moss, etc.). For LAI, canopy height, and thaw depth, we made measurements at 10 points spaced at 2 meter intervals along the plot centerline and parallel to the creek. LAI measurements were taken using an LAI-2000 Plant Canopy Analyzer (LI-COR Biosciences, Lincoln, NE). LAI is a unitless metric that represents the density of leaves, wood, and standing litter projecting above a sensor placed on the ground. Maximum canopy height was represented by the uppermost shrub branch or leaf within 15 cm of the each sampling point and was measured using a metal tape. We measured thaw depth using a metal thaw probe. Categorical descriptions of surficial geology and geomorphic landforms were recorded using standard classification systems developed for Arctic Alaska [Kreig and Reger, 1982; ADGGS, 1983; Williams, 1983; Rawlinson, 1993]. Finally, we recorded basic soil stratigraphy, surface organic thickness, soil particle texture, depth to saturated soils, pH, and EC and chemistry at small soil pits (~40 cm deep) established at a representative location within each plot.

description.para: Data were collected 21-27 August 2016 along the Dalton Highway, northern Alaska.

samplingDescription.para: Ecological field plots were established in riparian vegetation along discrete stream reaches, 2 or 3 plots per stream reach. Stream discharge measurements were made in the adjacent stream channel; we categorized the discharge regime for each stream reach as gaining (more discharge downstream) or losing (less discharge downstream; i.e., streamflow lost to groundwater).

project.title: Vegetation, Soils, and Environmental Data in Arctic Riparian Shrublands, North Slope, AK

attribute.attributeDefinition: Average of 5 LAI measurements taken at first/last 5 sampling points along 10 m transect

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: The LAI instrument was configured to report the mean of 5 individual LAI measurements. Hence the mean values are displayed at every fifth point along each transect, with -999 reported for the other points

attribute.attributeDefinition: Average of 5 LAI measurements taken at first/last 5 sampling points along 10 m transect

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: The LAI instrument was configured to report the mean of 5 individual LAI measurements. Hence the standard deviation values are displayed at every fifth point along each transect, with -999 reported for the other points

attribute.attributeDefinition: Depth of thaw

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: This field was recorded opportunistically along the transects. Thaw depths were not measured on transects
